sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Consider a graph G with 10 vertices having the degrees of each vertex given as follows:
degree(vertex 1) = 2
degree(vertex 2) = 3
degree(vertex 3) = 3
degree(vertex 4) = 1
degree(vertex 5) = 4
degree(vertex 6) = 2
degree(vertex 7) = 1
degree(vertex 8) = 2
degree(vertex 9) = 3
degree(vertex 10) = 3

Determine whether the graph G contains an Eulerian path or not. Also determine whether the graph G contains a Hamiltonian path or not. If yes, list the vertices in order of the path.
message_2:
To determine whether the graph G contains an Eulerian path, we need to check the degrees of the vertices. A graph has an Eulerian path if and only if it has at most two vertices with odd degrees. In this case, we have:

Odd degree vertices: vertex 2, vertex 3, vertex 5, vertex 9, and vertex 10 (5 odd degree vertices)

Since there are more than two vertices with odd degrees, the graph G does not contain an Eulerian path.

Now, let's determine whether the graph G contains a Hamiltonian path. A Hamiltonian path is a path that visits each vertex exactly once. Unfortunately, there is no general algorithm to determine whether a graph has a Hamiltonian path or not, as it is an NP-complete problem. However, we can try to find a Hamiltonian path manually.

One possible Hamiltonian path is:
vertex 4 -> vertex 1 -> vertex 6 -> vertex 8 -> vertex 5 -> vertex 2 -> vertex 3 -> vertex 9 -> vertex 10 -> vertex 7

So, the graph G contains a Hamiltonian path. The path is: 4-1-6-8-5-2-3-9-10-7.
